H0.text: Density of water is not necessary for determining the buoyant force acting on the small aluminum cube dropped into a beaker of water to determine buoyancy.

H1.text: Displaced volume is not necessary for determining the buoyant force acting on the small aluminum cube dropped into a beaker of water to assess buoyancy.

H2.text: Gravitational pull on Earth is not necessary in determining the buoyant force acting on a small aluminum cube that is dropped into a beaker of water to determine buoyancy.

H3.text: The density of the aluminum cube is not necessary for determining the buoyant force acting on a small aluminum cube that is dropped into a beaker of water to assess buoyancy.

A4.text: Archimedes' principle states that the upward buoyant force that is exerted on a body immersed in a fluid, whether fully or partially, is equal to the weight of the fluid that the body displaces.

A6.text: The force the liquid exerts on an object within the liquid is equal to the weight of the liquid with a volume equal to that of the object.

A7.text: The buoyancy force on a submerged body is directed in the opposite direction to gravity.
